body: ### Problem Given a buffer with the following content ``` a( b ) ``` with the cursor located above `b`, doing `vkol` to get the following visual selection and then doing `y` will result in the register `"` containing the trailing newline of the visual selection (i.e. `=vim.fn.getreg('"')` output will be `\n b\n`). However, given the same buffer and the same visual selection, using the following `operatorfunc` operator ```lua ---@param type 'line'|'char'|'block' _G.my_yank = function(type) local mode = type == "line" and "V" or type == "char" and "v" or vim.keycode("") local yanked = vim.fn.getregion(vim.fn.getpos("'["), vim.fn.getpos("']"), { type = mode }) local end_mark = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_mark(0, "]") -- __PRINT_VAR_START print([==[┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎end_mark╎ ┊1┊:]==], vim.inspect(end_mark)) -- __PRINT_VAR_END -- __PRINT_VAR_START print([==[┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎yanked╎ ┊1┊:]==], vim.inspect(yanked)) -- __PRINT_VAR_END end vim.keymap.set({ "x", "n" }, "", function(a) vim.o.operatorfunc = "v:lua._G.my_yank" return "g@" end, { expr = true }) ``` and typing `` will result in `┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎yanked╎ ┊1┊: { "", " b" }` being printed. Note the lack of a trailing empty string representing the trailing newline. The same happens for the `operatorfunc` operator when the newline is not selected at all. With the cursor above `b`, doing `k` to get the following visual selection also results in `┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎yanked╎ ┊1┊: { "", " b" }` being printed. So, no matter if the newline if visually selected or not, the `operatorfunc` operator sees the same values for the `[` and `]` marks. This happens because builtin operators (like `y`) get to operate on the range defined by `oap` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a8a097d178414e30ed758d332a74e649e43f105c/src/nvim/register.c#L1065-L1071 before its end is adjusted with `decl` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a8a097d178414e30ed758d332a74e649e43f105c/src/nvim/register.c#L1158-L1161 On the other hand, `operatorfunc` operators get the value adjusted by `decl` before they can even see it https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a8a097d178414e30ed758d332a74e649e43f105c/src/nvim/ops.c#L3160-L3163 I also found that, with the first visual selection mentioned, doing `y` results in `vim.api.nvim_buf_get_mark(0, ']')` returning `{2,2}` while `vim.api.nvim_buf_get_mark(0, '>')` returns `{2,3}` ### Steps to reproduce 1. `nvim --clean -u minimal.lua` where `minimal.lua` contains ```lua ---@param type 'line'|'char'|'block' _G.my_yank = function(type) local mode = type == "line" and "V" or type == "char" and "v" or vim.keycode "" local yanked = vim.fn.getregion(vim.fn.getpos "'[", vim.fn.getpos "']", { type = mode }) local end_mark = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_mark(0, "]") -- __PRINT_VAR_START print([==[┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎end_mark╎ ┊1┊:]==], vim.inspect(end_mark)) -- __PRINT_VAR_END -- __PRINT_VAR_START print([==[┆_G.my_yank┆ ╎yanked╎ ┊1┊:]==], vim.inspect(yanked)) -- __PRINT_VAR_END end vim.keymap.set({ "x", "n" }, "", function() vim.o.operatorfunc = "v:lua._G.my_yank" return "g@" end, { expr = true }) ``` 3. `ia()` `i` `O b` to end up with the same buffer mentioned above 4. `vkol` to end up with a visual selection including a trailing newline 5. `y` and `:=vim.fn.getreg('"')` to see that the yanked text contains at trailing newline 6. `gv` and `` to see that the text delimited by the `[` and `]` marks does not contain a trailing newline ### Expected behavior `operatorfunc` operators, just like builtin operators (`d`, `y, etc), should be able to distinguish between regions with and without a trailing newline. ### Nvim version (nvim -v) 0.11.6 ### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same? Yes, VIM - Vi IMproved 9.1 ### Operating system/version Arch linux latest ### Terminal name/version wezterm 20240203-110809-5046fc22 ### $TERM environment variable wezterm ### Installation pacman

comment_data.body:
Concise reproduction steps:

run `nvim --clean -u minimal.lua`

minimal.lua:

```lua
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, true, {
	"a(",
	"  b",
	")",
})

vim.fn.cursor(2, 3)

_G.operatorfunc = function(_) end
vim.o.operatorfunc = [[v:lua.operatorfunc]]
vim.cmd("normal! v$g@")

vim.print(vim.fn.getpos("'>")) -- this is { 0, 2, 4, 0 }
vim.print(vim.fn.getpos("']")) -- this is { 0, 2, 3, 0 }, but should be { 0, 2, 4, 0 }
```

This situation also occurs with the '< and '[ marks (when the first character of the region is an EOL)
